column13: The UNGC is the worldÃ¢ÂÂs largest corporate sustainability initiative. APA joined the UNGC in 2021, which involves committing to ten key principles, including relating to addressing forced and child labour, as well as other human rights abuses. We submitted APAÃ¢ÂÂs 2022 Communication on Progress to the UNGC to demonstrate our commitment to making the UNGC and its principles part of APAÃ¢ÂÂs strategy, culture and day-to-day operations, and we participated in UNGCÃ¢ÂÂs Early Adopter Program to communicate our progress in their new digital platform.

column6: Operations and suppliers ar significant risk for incidents of forced or compulsory labor
column13: In our FY21 Modern Slavery Statement, we noted we had reviewed our sourcing strategy for solar panels associated with solar farm construction projects. Given the inherent risk in solar panel manufacturing and the sourcing of raw materials in certain countries, we developed an alternative approach where APA would procure solar panels directly from international suppliers.
column20: Solar Panel, Alternative Approach, Sourcing Strategy

column13: Consideration of the risk across countries, suppliers and product /service categories, recognising social performance and specific international social impact risk data to drive supplier reviews and interventions. These reviews consider the control environment supporting key risk areas for suppliers, including legal requirements, confidence in assurance provided, and independent third-party reviews with brand and reputation impacts of transacting with the supplier.

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: APAÃ¢ÂÂs modern slavery risk management approach comprises three stages. Stage 1 - Data-driven risk assessment: using annual spending data, we conduct supplier screening using an external AI platform. Our products and service categories are mapped against the United Nations Standard Products and Services Codes (UNSPSC) and other databases that provide modern slavery analysis, including social hotspots database (SHDB) supplier and country risk information. Stage 2 - Desktop risk assessment: completed for each high-risk shortlisted supplier identified in stage 3. Stage 3 - Targeted Supplier Assessments: we engage a reputable external consultancy to provide additional due diligence information for the suppliers selected for targeted assessment.\t
column20: Data-Driven, Risk Assessment, Targeted Supplier Assessments

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: APAÃ¢ÂÂs Supplier Prequalification Program plays a vital role in APAÃ¢ÂÂs supply chain sustainability performance by tracking supplier commitments and performance in health, safety and environment, modern slavery, and social and community performance. Key suppliers are invited to join the Program based on the contract size, supply category, lack of readily available alternative sources and the risk to APA operations from an asset and employee perspective.
column14: 238 suppliers participated in APA's supplier prequalification program during FY22.
column20: Supplier Prequalification Program, Supply Chain, Social Performance

column6: Negative social impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column13: The Response Plan provides a framework for APA to appropriately manage a potential modern slavery allegation or incident involving a supplier. The Response Plan guides how we could assess whether we may have caused, contributed to, or be directly linked to modern slavery, in line with the United Nations Guiding Principles.
column14: No incidents or reports of modern slavery were received in FY22.
column20: Response Plan, Modern Slavery Allegation, United Nation

column6: Negative social impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column13: Our group-wide policy framework sets the foundation of our approach to managing modern slavery risks in our operations and supply chain. Key policies governing ethics and integrity at APA include the Code of Conduct, Diversity and Inclusion Policy, Anti-Bribery and Corruption Policy, etc.
column20: Policy Framework, Modern Slavery Risk, Operations, Supply Chain

column6: Negative social impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column13: We recognise that PPE can involve higher modern slavery risks. In FY22, we continued to monitor and consolidate safety clothing and PPE items. We moved PPE items to our approved supplierÃ¢ÂÂs manufactured brand to simplify modern slavery compliance management and secure stock supplies.\t
column14: It has further reduced the number of brand manufacturers in our approved range by 25%.
column20: Safety Clothing, PPE, modern slavery risks

column6: Negative social impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column13: During FY22, we developed and commenced the rollout of new 1.5-hour face-to-face training about modern slavery. The training was designed to highlight key potential risk areas for APA, detail how we are taking action to manage modern slavery risks and provide guidance on how employees can identify and report concerns or suspicions about modern slavery.
column14: At the end of June 2022, training delivery to the highest priority groups was complete, with four sessions held for 80 staff.
column20: Face-to-face training, Identifying and Reporting, Modern Slavery Risk

column6: Negative social impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column13: A general awareness video was produced and distributed to all employees. The video referenced everyday areas of life where modern slavery may be hidden, including food and clothing production. It detailed our selection process on a recent major project for solar panel suppliers, highlighting the potential modern slavery risk this type of purchase poses for APA.
column20: Video, Potential Modern Slavery Risk, Awareness

column6: Negative social impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column13: Working with industry peers to discuss their experience with mapping supply chains allowed APA to gain insights into the differing approaches to understanding supply chains and the challenges faced in embarking on this work. The greatest challenge common to those who have done this work is the reliance on Tier 1 suppliers to provide the necessary information.
column20: Supply Chains Mapping, Diverse Approach, Challenges

column6: Negative social impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column13: A high-risk area for modern slavery in Australia is the provision of cleaning services. APA procures various learning-related services for our corporate offices and sites around Australia.
column14: We have received positive feedback from many of our cleaning services suppliers. As of 1 October 2022, we have received acceptance from 65% of those suppliers.

column6: Negative social impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column13: As this statement outlines, we take various steps to prevent and mitigate our modern slavery risks. However, we recognise that it is also important we are prepared to respond to modern slavery-related allegations or incidents.

column6: Negative social impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column8: Development of Modern Slavery Response Plan
column13: The Response Plan aims to provide a framework for APA to appropriately manage a potential modern slavery allegation or incident involving a supplier. We worked with an external business and human rights advisory firm to assist us in aligning the Response Plan with the UNGPs.
